text:
e="preserve">In mathematics, a field is a certain kind of algebraic structure. In a field, one can add (formula_1), subtract (formula_1), multiply (formula_1) and divide (formula_1) two numbers (with division only possible if formula_1 is non-zero). A field is a special ring in which division is possible. Both the set of rational numbers and the set of real numbers are examples of fields. One can also use the symbol formula_1 as a variable for a field.
Examples of fields.
In fact, among the subsets of complex numbers, the largest field is formula_1 and the smallest field is formula_1. The set of integers, formula_1, is not a field, because the result of a division is not always an integer.
